Incident.Summary: Hmimmic Merry At-Lmulud was charged with DUI/DWI. DUI Folder 23-123.

IncidentAddress.IncAddrComment: OCEAN GTWY/ OLD OCEAN CITY BLVD

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
DUI Folder # 23-96-123
SUSPECT: Hmimic Merry At-Lmulud          
LICENSE # MD/ 10272194662
DUI CITATION # 3HD0VPH
SUBSEQUENT OFFENDER: Yes
ACCIDENT INVOLVED: No
VIDEO: Maryland State Police; Axon Evidence Video ID #: 23MSP017881. BWC Utilized.
 
TRAINING/CERTIFICATES:
  • I am trained in administering standardized field sobriety tests through the Maryland State Police and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA).
  • I have successfully completed Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement (ARIDE) training as of 2021.
  • I am trained and certified to operate RADAR and LIDAR through the Maryland State Police as of 2020.
  • I have apprehended more than 80 impaired drivers during my tenure with the Maryland State Police to date.

Phase #1 - Vehicle In Motion:
 
     On May 19, 2023, at approximately 1916 hours, I, Tfc. Pinto #7212 was on duty, operating unmarked Maryland State Police Patrol vehicle V-9, stationary in the area of eastbound Ocean Gateway at Old Ocean City Blvd, Berlin, Worcester County, Maryland when I received a lookout from the Maryland State Police Berlin Barrack for a black SUV, that almost ran off the roadway, traveling eastbound on Ocean Gateway at Ocean City Expressway. The Maryland State Police Berlin Barrack advised that they received multiple calls for the black SUV being all over the roadway.

Shortly after receiving the vehicle lookout, I observed a black SUV pass my patrol vehicle on eastbound Ocean Gateway at Old Ocean City Blvd. I entered eastbound Ocean Gateway at Old Ocean City Blvd to catch up to the black SUV. I caught up to and got behind the black SUV at eastbound Ocean Gateway at Worcester Hwy and I observed the vehicle was a black Mercedes Benz bearing Maryland registration, “70139CK.” While behind the black Mercedes Benz at eastbound Ocean Gateway at Worcester Hwy, I observed the vehicle change lanes from lane 2 into lane 1 with no other vehicles in front. I then observed the black Mercedes Benz jerk left to right and right to left within lane 1. I remained behind the black Mercedes Benz on eastbound Ocean Gateway east of Old Ocean City Blvd when I observed the vehicle cross the white dotted line, by approximately a half (1/2) of tires width, from lane 1 into lane 2, and weave back into lane 1. The black Mercedes Benz continued eastbound on Ocean Gateway at Old Ocean City Blvd when I observed the vehicle cross the white dotted line, from lane 1 into lane 2, by approximately a half (1/2) of tires width, and weave back into lane 1. The black Mercedes Benz continued eastbound on Ocean Gateway at Seahawk Road when I observed the vehicle to continue to jerk left to right and right to left within lane 2 as it came to a stop at the red traffic control device. I remained behind the black Mercedes Benz on eastbound Ocean Gateway east of Racetrack Road when I observed the brake lights activated on the vehicle when no other vehicle in front of the black Mercedes Benz was braking. The black Mercedes continued to jerk left to right and right to left within lane one at eastbound Ocean Gateway east of Racetrack Road. I continued behind the black Mercedes on Ocean Gateway at Racetrack Road when I observed the vehicle entering the left turn lane. While the black Mercedes entered the turn lane, I observed the vehicle cross the solid yellow line, by approximately one (1) tires width from the left turn lane into the shoulder/ median area of the roadway, and weave back into the left turn lane. The black Mercedes Benz came to a stop at the red traffic control device at eastbound Ocean Gateway at Racetrack Road and when the traffic control device turned green the vehicle remained stopped for several seconds when the vehicle in front of the black Mercedes had already entered the intersection. Once the black Mercedes Benz started moving, I observed the vehicle conduct a u-turn onto westbound Ocean Gateway at Racetrack Road. After conducting the u-turn, I observed the black Mercedes traveling in lane 2 on westbound Ocean Gateway at Racetrack Road, cross the dotted white line, by approximately one (1) tires width, into lane 1, and weave back into lane 2. The black Mercedes continued westbound Ocean Gateway west of Racetrack Road, when I observed the vehicle activate its right turn signal to conduct a right turn into the parking lot of Shea Performance and Auto Repair, located at 11129 Ocean Gateway, Berlin, Maryland from lane 2. While the black Mercedes Benz conducted the right turn, I activated my emergency equipment to conduct a traffic stop on the vehicle. The Black Mercedes Benz came to a stop in the parking lot of Shea Performance and Auto Repair. 


Phase #2 - Personal Contact


After the vehicle came to a stop, I exited my patrol vehicle and began to approach the passenger side window of the vehicle. While approaching the passenger side window, I observed the black Mercedes Benz began moving forward. At this time, I knocked on the passenger side closed windows, and yelled to the driver to place his vehicle in park and he complied. The driver then opened the passenger side front window and immediately detected the strong odor of an alcoholic beverage and the odor of urine emitting from the passenger compartment of the vehicle. I also observed the front of the driver’s pants were wet as if he urinated on himself. After I made contact with the driver at the passenger side front window, TFC Phillips and TFC Furness made contact with the driver at the front driver’s side window. 
 
I explained to the driver the reason for the stop and requested his driver’s license and registration. While the driver retrieved his license and registration, I observed the driver lift the center console of the vehicle, and inside I observed multiple empty Fireball Whiskey airplane bottle alcoholic beverages. Once the driver handed me his license, I identified the driver as Hmimic Merry At-Lmulud (W/M 01/15/1966), by his Maryland driver’s license. I asked the At-Lmulud if he was still at the Berlin address on his license and he advised he was. I asked the driver why he pulled into the Shea Performance and Auto Repair parking lot and he stated, “I’m a poet and a writer,” and advised he came here to write. I asked At-Lmulud again why he pulled into Shea Performance and Auto Repair, and he stated, “I live here, I live in Glen Riddle.” I explained to At-Lmulud that he was not located at Glen Riddle. I asked At-Lmulud again why he pulled into Shea Performance and Auto Repair and he again advised he is a poet and a writer. I explained to At-Lmulud that he is not answering my question. While speaking with At-Lmulud I observed his eyes to be blood shot and glassy and his speech to be slow and slurred. I also observed At-Lmulud movements to be slow and lethargic.

 At this time, I walked around the front of the black Mercedes Benz and made contact with At-Lmulud at the open driver’s side window, and I asked him to step out of the vehicle and he complied. While At-Lmulud stepped out of the vehicle I observed his movements to be slow and lethargic. Once At-Lmulud stepped from the vehicle, I asked him to step to the front of my patrol vehicle and he complied. While walking to the front of my patrol vehicle, I observed At-Lmulud lose his balance to the right while he was walking next to me and use his right foot to catch him self from falling.

Phase #3 - Pre Arrest Screening


While in front of my patrol vehicle, I asked At-Lmulud how many of the Fire Ball whiskey bottles are located in his center console and he stated, “it doesn’t matter, you know what I lost my mom she passed away, and I was suppose to go see her.” At-Lmulud then stated, “I am a human activist.” I asked At-Lmulud how many of the Fireball Whiskey drinks he had and he stated, “not a lot.” I asked At-Lmulud what is not a lot and he stated, “like two three.” I asked At-Lmulud what else he has had besides the Fireball whiskey drinks and he stated, “I’m in to poems.” I explained to At-Lmulud I am asking him how many alcoholic beverages he has had and he stated, “I know all of that, I am a human activist, and I know people should not drink and drive.” At-Lmulud then looked at the sun and stated, “man so beautiful.” I asked At-Lmulud to remain where he was standing, with TFC. Phillips and TFC Furness, while I grabbed my notepad out of my patrol vehicle and he complied.

After retrieving my notepad from my patrol vehicle, I returned to At-Lmulud, and explained to him that I would like to run him through some test to make sure he is okay to operate the vehicle to get home safely. I then asked At-Lmulud if he would submit to Standardized Field Sobriety tests  and he stated, “what if I say no.” I explained to At-Lmulud that if he refuses the tests I will have to place him under arrest for driving under the influence based off the observation’s I have already observed. At-Lmulud stated, “then I have no choice.” I explained to At-Lmulud that he does have a choice. I continued to explain to At-Lmulud that if he does the tests I will look for observations of impairment and If I feel he doesn’t show signs of impairment he would be free to drive home. I also explained that if he does the tests and shows signs of impairment he would be placed under arrest for driving under the influence of alcohol. At-Lmulud stated, “so I don’t have a choice.” I again explained to At-Lmulud that he does have a choice. I asked At-Lmulud if he wants to do the tests and he stated, “no I don’t.” I advosed At-Lmulud I am going to ask him one more time if he wants to do the test and as I did, he began stepping to his left as if he was trying to step away from TFC Phillps, TFC Furness, and I.  
At this time, I stepped towards At-Lmulud, grabbed his left wrist with my left hand using an open hand grip, reached around his back with my right hand, grabbed his right bicep with my right hand using an open hand grip, and gave verbal commands to place his hands behind his back. I then turned At-Lmulud around to face away from me by forcing his left wrist with my left hand behind his back, using an open hand grip, and pulled his right bicep with my right hand, using an open hand grip, towards me. As I turned At-Lmulud around, I felt him tense his arms. I gave At-Lmulud verbal commands to stop resisting, and passed off control of his left arm to Tfc. Phillips. While passing off At-Lmulud’s left wrist to Tfc. Phillips, I placed my left hand on At-Lmulud’s lower back, using an open hand, pushed with my left hand while sliding my right wrist against At-Lmulud’s wrist, and forced his right arm behind his back. Once At-Lmulud’s right arm was behind his back, I open hand grabbed his wrist with my right and left hand and held his right arm against his lower back. I then held At-Lmulud’s right wrist, with an open hand grip, against his lower back, and retrieved my handcuffs with my left hand.

While Tfc. Phillips controlled At-Lmulud’s left arm, I placed my handcuffs on At-Lmulud’s right wrist. Once the handcuffs were secured on At-Lmulud’s right wrist, I used an open hand and grabbed his left wrist and secured the handcuffs on his left wrist.
 
Arrest

 Based on the following totality of circumstances, I had reason to believe At-Lmulud was driving a motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol:
  • At-Lmulud admitting to consuming alcoholic beverages.
  • At-Lmulud Failure to Obey a Properly Placed Traffic Control Device.
  • At-Lmulud had the strong odor of an alcoholic beverage admitting form his breath and person.
  • At-Lmulud’s eyes were bloodshot and glass.
  • At-Lmulud urinated on himself.
  • At-Lmulud was argumentative.

At 1926 hours, I placed At-Lmulud under arrest. I placed At-Lmulud into the front passenger seat of my patrol vehicle. I then entered my patrol vehicle and detected the strong odor of an alcoholic beverage that was not present prior to placing At-Lmulud inside.

Without incident, I transported At-Lmulud to the Maryland State Police Berlin Barrack “V’, located at 9758 Ocean Gateway, Berlin, Worcester County, Maryland. During Transport, I continued to detect the strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from At-Lmulud’s person. 

While at the Barrack, I placed a paper copy of the DR-15 Advice of Rights in front of At-Lmulud and I played the MVA Audio version of the DR-15 from the MVA website and asked At-Lmulud to follow along. 

After the DR-15 was completed, At-Lmulud advised at 2010 hours that he agreed to submit to take the breath test. 

Intoximeter Test:

Sgt. Harper, a certified EC/IR II operator, checked At-Lmulud’s mouth for foreign objects and nothing was located. At 2022 hours, Sgt. Harper administered the breath test with a result of 0.20 grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath.

At-Lmulud was given his paperwork and citations and released to a valid sober driver from the Maryland State Police Berlin Barrack.

Charges
  1. Driving Vehicle While Under the influence of Alcohol (3HD0VPH)
  2. Driving Vehicle While Under the Influence of Alcohol Per Se (3HF0VPH)
  3. Driving Vehicle While Impaired by Alcohol (3HG0VPH)
  4. Driver Fail To Obey a Properly Placed Traffic Control Device Instructions (3HH0VPH)
  5. Reckless Driving (3HK0VPH)
  6. Negligent Driving (3HJ0VPH)
 
Case Closed by Arrest.

All events occurred in Worcester County, Maryland.

SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT

This incident was audibly and visually recorded on bodywork camera. 

I arrived on scene with TFC Pinto #7212 and TFC Phillips #7211 for the unsafe operation of the black Mercedes, Maryland Registration 70139CK.  Once the driver was out of the vehicle, TFC Pinto explained and offered to the driver, At-Lmulud, to submit to Standardized Field Sobriety Tests.  At-Lmulud ultimately refused all tests and TFC Pinto advised At-Lmulud he was being placed under arrest at that time for DUI.  At-Lmulud did not want to be arrested and began passively resisting by refusing to put his hands behind his back.  TFC Pinto and TFC Phillips were giving At-Lmulud verbal commands to stop resisting.  TFC Pinto had both hands on At-Lmulud's arm, and so I stepped behind TFC Pinto to get his handcuffs out for him.  TFC Pinto placed At-Lmulud in handcuffs and I advised the Barrack over the radio that At-Lmulud was in custody.  At this point I walked back to our patrol vehicles to find trash bags to cover the seat for transport due to At-Lmulud having urinated on himself.

All events occurred in Worcester County, Maryland.

Maryland State Police
Berlin Barrack “V” (9096)
TFC R. Phillips #7211
May 20th, 2023
 
Maryland State Police Patrol Vehicle – V-35 is a marked Ford Explorer that is equipped with an MVR system. This incident was also audibly and visually recorded on Axon Body Camera. All videos associated with the incident are labeled (23MSP017881).
 
  • Driver/Defendant: Hmimic Merry At-Lmulud
  • Date of Birth: 01/15/1966

Narrative:

   On May 19th, 2023 at 1916 hours, I (TFC Phillips #7211), responded to the area of Eastbound Ocean Gateway in the area of Seahawk to assisted TFC Pinto #7212 with a possible drunk driver. The Berlin Barrack had received several calls about the vehicle.

   I observed the vehicle, a black Mercedes, in lane 1 with TFC Pinto behind the vehicle. I observed the vehicle weave from left to the right inside the lane. The vehicle came to a stop in the turn lane from Eastbound Ocean Gateway to Highway 589. Despite the traffic light turning green, the vehicle stayed stopped for an unusual amount of time. The vehicle then made a U turn and pulled into 11129 Ocean Gateway, Berlin, MD 21811.

    I exited my patrol vehicle to assist TFC Pinto on the traffic stop. I approached the driver's side window. I immediately detected the strong odor of alcoholic beverage and urine emanating from inside the vehicle. I observed the operator to have a wet spot on his crotch and inner thighs. When asked for his license and registration, he opened his center console. Inside were two empty Fireball liquor shot bottles. He then slammed it shut.

  The operator was identified through his Maryland Driver's license as Hmimic Merry At-Lmulude. Due to the odor of alcoholic beverage and Fireball liquor being in plain view, he was asked to step out of the vehicle by TFC Pinto. While standing in front of TFC Pinto’s patrol vehicle, he was asked to submit to Field Sobriety Tests. He refused to submit to these tests.

   Due to TFC Pinto's observations of impairment. He was placed under arrest for Driving under the influence of alcohol (BWC 0725). While being handcuffed, At-Lmulude put his arms to his side and tensed (BWC 0734). I placed my left hand on his left bicep with a soft open hand grip. I placed my right hand on his left forearm with a soft open hand grip. I attempted to guide his arm behind his back. He tensed again and attempted to pull his arm forward. TFC Pinto and I continued to ask him to place his hands behind his back. Due to him resisting handcuffing, I switched my hands and pulled his arm behind his back (BWC 0738). I lightly pressed him against the patrol vehicle. TFC Pinto completed his handcuffing and I released my right hand from his arm.

   I continued to explain the reason he was placed under arrest. At-Lmulude leaned back resisting while TFC Pinto was patting him down for weapons. Due to this, I placed my left hand with an open grip on his bicep and then used my right hand to press him against the patrol vehicle (BWC 1006). I also used my left hand to press him against the vehicle.He was then guided to the passenger side of the vehicle. The cuffs were readjusted by TFC Pinto. He was placed inside the vehicle. I assisted in buckling his seat belt. I then followed TFC Pinto to the Berlin Barrack to assist.

Once at the barrack, I used my right hand to guide At-Lmulude inside the Barrack (BWC 2620). While inside the barrack, TFC Pinto conducted his secondary search. I continued to use my right hand to guide At-Lmulude (BWC 2800). At-Lmulude walked by himself to the DUI processing room. I uncuffed him while inside the processing room. That concluded my physical involvement with At-Lmulude.

All events did occur in Worcester County, Maryland.
